IFES – Federal Institute of Espírito Santo São Mateus Brazil The environmental impact on the energy sector has become a significant concern, necessitating the implementation of Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS) to enhance the energy efficiency of buildings, reduce costs and greenhouse gas emissions, and ensure user comfort. This paper presents a novel approach to provide optimal day-ahead energy management plans in smart homes with Photovoltaic/Thermal (PVT) systems, aiming to achieve a balance between energy cost and user comfort. This multi-objective problem employs the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III as the optimization algorithm and the Nonlinear Auto-regressive with External Input to forecast the day-ahead meteorological variables, which serve as inputs to predict the PVT electrical and heat production in the thermal resistance model. The HEMS benefits from the time-of-use tariff due to the flexibility provided by the energy storage from a battery bank and a boiler. Furthermore, it performs a load scheduling for 10 controllable loads based on three feature parameters to characterize occupant behavior. A study case analysis revealed a cost reduction of approximately 66% in the solution close to the knee of the Pareto curve (S3 solution). The environmental impact on the energy sector has become a The PVT heat production was sufficient to meet the thermal demand of the showers. The proposed hybrid battery management model effectively eliminated the export of electricity to the grid, reducing consumption during peak periods and the maximum peak demand. Graphical abstract Keywords Demand side management Day-ahead forecasting Battery energy storage system PVT system Occupant behavior modeling Optimization algorithm Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Frequent disasters related to climate change have made the decarbonization of the economy a priority in global public policy formulation in recent times [1]. The electrification of the economy and society plays a central role in achieving carbon neutrality to limit the impact of climate change [2], whose demand must be supported by the increase of renewable energy sources production combined with efficient use of electrical energy [3]. In 2022, the operations of buildings are responsible for 30% of world energy consumption and 26% of direct and indirect emissions [4], making the quest for sustainability also present in this sector. In this context, the HEMS concept emerges as a new paradigm, characterized by including smartness in the operation of buildings by a digital processing system capable of performing optimized control of behind-the-meter resources, whose objective is to provide the required comfort for end users at the lowest cost [5]. The HEMS is able to take advantage of different energy tariff regulations with flexible pricing schemes, such as real-time pricing, TOU and critical peak pricing, being an opportunity for the users to perform Load Scheduling (LS) to obtain a reduction with energy acquisition costs [6]. But LS algorithms must also take into account the habit of using equipment by users to ensure their comfort, which must be measured using appropriate metrics, which are generally obtained through the history of equipment consumption or by comparing it with typical values defined by standards (such as ideal water temperature for bathing or indoor air temperature) [7]. A widely used method in the literature to reduce intervention in user habits is to divide loads into non-flexible and flexible (also subdivided into deferrable and thermal loads) loads [8]. Non-flexible loads are usually the most essential in certain domestic activities and have low energy consumption, i.e., their use does not generate significant financial impacts, as is the case of lamps. Deferrable appliances are a class of equipment that has defined cycles of operation with a known duration and power consumption, such as washing machines and dishwashers. Note the HEMS can control the use of this type of appliance through smart plugs and this simple model (constant power consumption) has a relatively low error. However, thermal loads require more refined modeling to ensure good accuracy, such as water heating systems [9]. With the limited reserves of fossil fuels and their high emission of greenhouse gases, it is essential to invest in alternative energy sources to mitigate such effects, highlighting the Photovoltaic (PV) one because of its current competitive cost, abundance of resources, reduced maintenance, and modularity [10]. Given the waste of thermal energy in PV modules, PVT technology couples a heat exchanger to the PV module to transfer some of the available heat to a working fluid that can be used in low-temperature applications [11], such as hot water for bathing. So, PVT is a hybrid solar system capable of simultaneously producing electricity and heat, being able to increase considerably the overall efficiency of the system. Another advantage of this technology is the reduction of the cell’s operating temperature, which results in higher values of electrical efficiency and the cell’s lifetime [12]. However, to achieve high performance, the generation of thermal energy must be adequately combined with the local demand because, if the generated heat is not used, the temperature of the working fluid increases, reducing the thermal exchange with the PV cells, which causes a reduction in thermal efficiency, in addition to a reduction in electrical generation due to the increase in the operating temperature of the cell. Therefore, hot water for bathing in smart homes is a good destination for the heat generated in PVTs. Based on their advantages, PVT modules can achieve an overall efficiency of up to 70%, with thermal utilization being the main factor of this high performance (reaching up to 50% of thermal efficiency) [13]. However, to achieve high performance, the generation of thermal energy must be adequately combined with the local demand because, if the generated heat is not used, the temperature of the working fluid increases, reducing the thermal exchange with the PV cells, a fact that causes the reduction of thermal efficiency, in addition to a reduction in electrical generation due to the increase in the operating temperature of the cell. In smart homes, heated water for bathing is a suitable destination for PVT thermal generation [14]. In this work, this water is stored in a boiler to reduce thermal losses, but when the water temperature in the boiler is lower than the required for the bath, a supplementary electric resistance heating system is driven to guarantee this temperature for the user. When the Smart Home (SH) has generation with intermittent power sources (such as PVT), day-ahead energy management becomes an even harder task and requires robust methods due to the stochastic and variable nature of the source [15]. So, it is necessary to accurately forecast the meteorological data to estimate the electrical and thermal generation of the PVT, with Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) being the most used technique in the literature to solve the problem [16]. In addition, to promote more flexibility in energy management, optimize the use of resources, and take advantage of flexible pricing schemes of energy, the use of electrical (batteries) and thermal energy storage elements (such as boiler) combined with LS are proven efficient in reducing the acquisition cost and ensuring the comfort of users [17]. The day ahead optimal scheduling problems considering Demand Side Management (DSM) can be complex and need a suitable optimization algorithm, since the problem may become unfeasible from a mathematical or computational point of view [18], especially when considering a multi-objective approach and models with nonlinear equations. To solve this type of problem, the optimization methods based on evolutionary meta-heuristics, such as NSGA-III, and Multi-Objective Grey Wolf Optimizer (MOGWO), are the most adequate techniques [19]. Given the challenges presented and the importance of implementing effective energy HEMS, this paper presents a new methodology to perform optimal day-ahead scheduling considering thermal and electrical energy management in Smart Homes with PVT systems installed on the rooftop modeled in a multi-objective formulation to reach a compromise between energy cost and users’ comfort. 1.1 Related works HEMS is the subject of many recent works in the specialized literature. Due to the trend of including energy sources and energy storage systems in the SH architecture, and considering multi-objective formulations with conflicting goals, the proposed methodologies need to become more sophisticated to achieve satisfactory results and still have several challenges to overcome. The main focus of the first published works was to carry out purely load-scheduling to take advantage of flexible pricing schemes of energy to reduce costs and/or peak load reduction, as in the work proposed by [20], which implemented the algorithm for load transfer to off-peak hours in 2 flexible loads (dishwasher and washing machine) in a 4-person household. The results show a reduction of up to 24% in peak demand with the application of the method, but just applying LS is limited when compared to the potential that a DSM program can obtain and the method does not take into account the comfort of users, which is an essential requirement to evaluate when applying LS. The work [21] performs a LS in a multi-objective formulation to simultaneously reduce the energy cost and guarantee the users’ comfort solved by Constructive Heuristic (CH) join as Genetic Algorithm (GA). In addition to user comfort, the inclusion of renewable generation sources in the SH is essential to reduce energy costs and make the operation of the SH more sustainable. Optimization of energy cost subject to a required level of comfort defined by the user is solved in [22] by a Multi-Start Meta-heuristic (MSM) with the support of a Constructive Heuristic and a Refinement Heuristic, followed by the analysis of the inclusion of photovoltaic systems after optimization. Although the results show significant savings and an attractive return on investment, not considering photovoltaic generation in the optimization algorithm modeling is an critical limitation of the proposal. A robust optimization for grid-connected households considering PV generation uncertainty solved by Quadratic Programming (QP) was proposed in [23], which reaches an expressive cost reduction of around 25% compared to other algorithms in the literature. Many works consider the use of PVT systems to provide electrical and thermal energy to buildings. The comparison of a water-based PVT system with a solar thermal system combined with conventional PV was carried out by [24] and the results show that PVT achieves 6 percentage points higher exergetic efficiency. The performance of multi-energy complementary systems (including PVT) for a net Zero Energy Building (nZEB) has been analyzed in [25] and solved by the Response Surface Method (RSM) to minimize Overall Electricity Consumption (OEC) and Life Cycle Cost (LCC) while maximizing the Coefficient Of Performance (COP). The results show a good complementary between PVT and Combined Cooling, Heating and Power (CCHP). While [26] analyzed the PVT performance on three different days, and concluded that the environmental conditions and the use of hot water have significant effects on the energy and exergy outputs, i.e., the hot water use profile influences the PVT performance. The results of the LS are affected by the usage profile of the applications in the house, which varies drastically according to the user’s lifestyle, work routine, and preferences, which are highly random and complex, as well as the bio-climatic zones and architecture of the house. Therefore, the proper classification and modeling of loads, as well as the definition of appropriate metrics to quantify user comfort, are essential and difficult tasks to be performed prior to the application of LS and were not considered in almost all previous studies. Optimal scheduling for deferrable and thermostatically controlled loads has been implemented by [8], taking into account the stochastic behavior of the occupants to define the comfort of the users by applying the Markov chain Monte Carlo method based on the Metropolis Hasting algorithm, using as input feature parameters (switch-on time, operating time, temperature set-point, and others). The problem has been formulated in a multi-objective manner using NSGA-III and Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to an Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) methods to simultaneously reduce the energy costs, emissions, and the Average Ramping Index (ARI), with results respectively showing a reduction of 6.25%, 6.3% and 15.0% compared to the benchmark. Day-ahead power forecasting requires high accuracy, and NNs have been widely used in the literature to predict the generation of many types of energy sources. In the paper [27], three types of NNs are compared to predict the short-term power generation of an amorphous PV plant, and the Temporal Convolutional Network shows the best performance in all scenarios. The NARX performed well in predicting wind speed in [28], i.e. indirectly the wind generation. Work [8] developed an innovative method to model occupant behavior in smart homes but did not define a metric to measure the users’ comfort. Comfort is the characteristics caused or created in an environment that satisfies human needs and it is worth noting that the feeling of comfort varies from person to person. In the literature, articles use different methods to meet the required user comfort. In [29], comfort is divided into 3 segments (visual, thermal, and air quality) and the criterion is met using inequality constraints, i.e., the parameter must be within a minimum and maximum value. While in [30], a comfort matrix has been created based on the average hourly use of devices throughout the year, divided into 3 discrete comfort levels using the k-means method. However, measuring comfort in discrete levels is not a good choice because the optimization algorithm loses information about the exact time when the user prefers to use the equipment. In this paper, we have improved this method by creating a probabilistic approach where comfort is defined by a frequency histogram of the appliance’s use, using its historical energy consumption as input data. The advantages of this new approach are the simplicity of generating the histogram and the fact that the results are continuous data. With the evolution of technology and the reduction of costs, the use of Battery Banks (BB) provides flexibility to HEMS to increase gains in energy tariff regulations with flexible pricing schemes tariffs when performing peak-shaving and load-shifting, as presented in [31], which used Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) to minimize the peak load and electricity cost and the results reach a cost reduction up to 71.39%. The work developed in [32,33] aims to define the optimal capacity of the BB and simultaneously manage the energy of an SH, whose models include battery degradation, which is necessary for long-term studies. The DSM strategy should be robust to different types of tariff schemes, as the work in [34] tested 5 DSM methods in 4 tariff scenarios, showing variation in DSM performance in each scenario. Therefore, in this article, the battery energy management model developed in [35] has been implemented, which has some parameters adjusted by the optimization algorithm, making it adaptable to different consumer demand profiles and adopted energy prices. The only article found in the literature that considers PVT generation in day-ahead scheduling in HEMS is [36]. However, the work does not apply occupant behavior modeling, metrics to quantify the comfort of the users, and the use of BB in the SH architecture. Finally, Table 1 summarizes the main information from related works in the literature. 1.2 Our contributions After presenting related works, it is evident that there are no available studies that simultaneously investigate the use of PVT systems in an LS problem that quantifies the user’s comfort. This represents a significant gap in the existing literature and a novelty of the work. The objective of this work is to enhance the understanding of how the flexibility promoted by PVT systems, combined with battery bank and LS, should be managed in the HEMS context to reach a compromise between energy cost and user comfort. The PVT electrical and thermal generation has been modeled using a validated thermal resistance method, which includes the boiler storage losses. Additionally, a hot water management system has been developed to guarantee the ideal bathing temperature for users and to consume the minimum amount of electricity to heat water. The second contribution consists of a simple-to-implement and novel method of modeling the stochastic behavior of the occupants for deferrable and thermal loads, with very few similar approaches in the literature, where comfort is defined by a frequency histogram of the appliance’s use, using its historical energy consumption as input data. This approach has the advantage of generating continuous comfort values (allowing the optimization algorithm to find the best time to schedule the appliances) and the fact that the histogram can be updated online, thus capturing changes in consumption habits over time. The proposed approach also uses a battery energy management method, developed by the authors of this work, that performs load shifting and peak shaving, focusing on optimizing the values of the objective function and is robust to different scenario profiles (objective functions, load profiles, tariff schemes, etc.) since it has parameters that are chosen by the optimization algorithm. Finally, the last contribution involves a case study, based on real data, to evaluate the performance of the methodology using NSGA-III as the optimization technique and NARX to predict the day-ahead meteorological data (solar irradiance, temperature, and wind speed) that are input to the PVT generation model. The rest of the article is organized into six sections: Section 2 presents the architecture and strategy of the implemented HEMS. The problem formulation and the proposed algorithm optimization is presented in Section 3. Section 4 shows the results obtained in the case study and their discussion is presented in Section 5. Finally, the paper’s conclusions and recommendations for future works are presented in Section 6. 2 HEMS architecture and strategy The HEMS implemented in this work consists of jointly performing the day-ahead LS, the PVT electrical and thermal energy generation forecast, and the battery energy management system to define optimal operating plans for the SH in order to simultaneously maximize user comfort and reduce energy costs, among which one will be selected by the end users. Fig. 1 shows the architecture of the proposed HEMS connected to Distribution Network Operator (DNO). where P d , P t , P n c and P S H are the electrical power consumption of deferrable, thermal, the aggregate non-controllable loads and the entire SH, respectively. P e l is the electrical power generated by PVT, P n e t is the net power in the SH ( P S H - P e l ), P b a t and P g r i d are the power stored or injected by the BB and into the grid, respectively. η c h , η r t and η d i s are respectively the battery charging, round trip and discharge efficiencies. Q u is the heat transferred to the working fluid in the PVT heat exchanger, Q b is the heat removed from boiler to during baths and Q s is the total heat consumed during the showers. As shown in Fig. 1, the loads are divided into non-controllable, deferrable, and thermal loads, all of which have a smart meter installed to measure the power consumed with an integration time of 15 min. The aggregate consumption history of the non-controllable loads is used to estimate their next-day consumption. On the other hand, the deferrable and thermal loads are used to characterize the stochastic behavior of the occupants and after this characterization, the optimization algorithm schedules these loads to improve the objective functions of the problem. Finally, the solar irradiance, wind speed, and temperature obtained from a meteorological station, integrated at 1-hour time intervals, are used as input to NARX to perform the day-ahead PVT generation forecast. 2.1 PVT power forecasting Historical weather data from a meteorological station are stored in the database of the HEMS data processing system, which serves as input data to NARX for training, validation, and testing of the network. So, the production of thermal and electrical power from the PVT is obtained using the thermal resistance method using the forecasted meteorological data for the following day as input. 2.1.1 Forecasting day-ahead meteorological data using NARX ANN are computational models inspired by an animal’s central nervous system that is capable of performing machine learning and they are widely used in data prediction. NARX is based on a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) neural network, defined as having one or more hidden layers with an indeterminate number of neurons, where inputs, hidden layers, and output layers are connected using adaptive weights and have associated bias values (except the input layer). These weights and bias values are changed by the learning process to find their optimal values based on the applied evaluation metric, where the Mean Squared Error (MSE) has been applied as the loss function, which is typically employed in regression problems. The basic difference of NARX is that it has a feedback loop for the output and exogenous input limited to a number of delay intervals (d), this short-term memory has a profound impact on the learning capacity and performance of the network in for time-sequenced data. A typical NARX model is described in Eq. (1). (1) y ˆ ( i + 1 ) = f ( x 1 ( i ) , x 1 ( i − 1 ) , x 1 ( i − 2 ) . . . x n ( i − d ) , y ( i ) , y ( i − 1 ) , y ( i − 2 ) . . . y ( i − d ) ) where y ˆ ( i + 1 ) is predict variable in the interval i + 1 , x 1 ( i ) , x 1 ( i − 1 ) . . . x n ( i − d ) is the historical values of each exogenous input limited to a lag time of d and y ( i ) , y ( i − 1 ) , y ( i − 2 ) . . . y ( i − d ) is the historical values targeted variable also limited to a lag time d . LSTM networks are one of the most popular types of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and are well-suited for time series forecasting [37]. LSTM networks indeed excel at capturing long-term dependencies in time series data, while NARX models are known for their ability to model nonlinear relationships and incorporate exogenous variables. In scenarios like energy consumption forecasting, where external factors like ambient temperature play a crucial role, NARX models can be advantageous due to their flexibility in incorporating such additional information. By including relevant exogenous variables, NARX models can enhance prediction accuracy by capturing the influence of external factors on the time series behavior. In addition, NARX has a lower computational cost, making the processing architecture of the algorithm more compact and cheaper. To achieve day-ahead forecasting, the NARX network utilizes historical data from a meteorological station close to the PVT generator. The historical data has a 4-year time horizon, integrated with 1-hour time intervals, resulting in 35,040 entry patterns (24 × 365 × 4), and each one contains the following variables: time in U T C , precipitation in mm, atmospheric pressure in atm , solar irradiance ( G ) in W/m 2 , ambient temperature ( T a ) in ∘ C , relative humidity in % , wind direction in ∘ , wind gust and wind speed ( v ) in m/s, forming a input matrix ( X ) with dimension of 35,040 entry pattern ( k ) × 8 variables ( m ). Before applying the NARX, a Min–Max normalization has been applied to enhance the algorithm convergence and performance. Once the data has been normalized, to perform a forecast with a 24-hour time horizon (day-ahead), the daily data for each input variable is standardized into a vector of 24 elements to represent its daily profile, i.e., with this new standardization, each entry pattern will contain 168 attributes (7 input variables × 24 interval times), while each input pattern will have 24 attributes corresponding to the 24 daily values of the variable to be forecast. Finally, the variables to be predicted ( G , v , T a ) are shifted by in 1 one entry pattern (24 h) to form the NARX network targets (one variable per procedure). In this way, 3 NARX networks are trained, validated, and tested with the same input X n (the input X normalized), but each network has as a target one of the variables G , v , and T a . 2.1.2 PVT power modeling In this work, the thermal resistance method has been applied to calculate the electrical and thermal power generated by the PVT, which determines the temperature in each layer of the PVT and allows such generation to be calculated. In this case, a day-ahead load forecasting algorithm such as NARX or LSTM can be used, using historical consumption as input data. First, the consumption history of these loads is necessary to obtain parameters that characterize their consumption profile (called feature parameters), in this work 3 feature parameters are used: turn-on times ( t o ), duration per cycle ( c d ), and the frequency distribution of use ( f ). Among these parameters, t o ( j ) and c d ( j ) for a specific equipment j are defined as discrete parameters, i.e., they will be input to the optimization algorithm as a discrete value defined by the mode of its daily frequency distribution. An arbitrary example of “turn-on times” and “duration per cycle” parameters definition for the washing machine is shown in Fig. 4. Based on the example shown in Fig. 4, the dishwasher ( j ) is turned on once a day on 56% of the days. As a result, we have assigned a value of 1 to its t o ( j ) parameter because it represents the distribution mode. Likewise, this dishwasher operates for around 30 min in 65% of instances when it is turned on, resulting in a c d ( j ) value of 30 min (or 2 time intervals). In contrast, the parameter f is a probabilistic input data for the optimization algorithm represented by the daily distribution frequency of equipment use. The distribution frequency of use of generic equipment j is given by Eqs. (21) and (22). (21) f ( i , j ) = N h t o ( i , j ) ∑ i = 1 N i N h t o ( i , j ) (22) ∑ i = 1 N i f ( i , j ) = 1 where f ( i , j ) is the percentage of use the equipment j in the interval i , N h t o ( i , j ) is the number of times that the controllable equipment j is in operation in the interval i in the historical series of consumption and N i is the number of time interval to represent a useful day (96 in this work). Finally, the Eq. (22) means that the sum of the probabilities of using a specific equipment j equipment throughout the day is equal to 1, i.e., f ( i , j ) is a probability density distribution. When constructing the probability frequencies of N j controllable equipment, we have a comfort matrix with dimensions ( N j ) × N i that represents the comfort of the users when using the equipment as a function of the time interval, based on the comfort matrix proposed in [30], but with the advantage of being a simple probabilistic approach with continuous values, making it easier for the optimization algorithm to schedule the loads at the most appropriate time possible. Finally, to quantify users’ comfort concerning the programmed use of a generic equipment j scheduled by the optimization algorithm, the average of f ( j ) values, while equipment j is turned on ( f p ( i , j ) = 1 ) , was used as a metric. In applying this metric, the equipment tends to be allocated by the optimization algorithm in a period that is often used to achieve a higher comfort level. In addition, to allow the users to indicate the equipment that they prefer to keep using in periods of higher comfort, a priority vector ( p r i ) with dimension N j controllable loads has been created, with discrete numbers varying from 1 to 5, where 1 is assigned to the equipment that they least care about to change the moment of use, while the value of 5 to those most prefers to keep using during periods of higher comfort. The overall user comfort ( U c ) has been defined in Eq. (23). Since the energy consumption and generation profiles, the adopted energy tariff, and the objective functions change for different case studies, the energy management model must be robust enough to cope with these changes. For this motivation, this paper applies the hybrid battery management model proposed and presented in detail in [35], whose strategy includes 5 operating modes. In the first 2 modes, the battery is charged or discharged to perform predefined actions to avoid exporting energy to the grid or importing energy in the moments of the highest price. On the other hand, in the last 3 operating modes, the optimization algorithm searches for optimal values of the vector P c d (the percentage of power that the battery will charge or discharge in a given period p and varies from −1 to 1) and the variable D p e a k (the power threshold value required for the battery to initiate the peak shaving task) to obtain the best values of the objective function, making the method robust enough to variations in load profiles and different tariff schemes. In addition, the battery modeling should take into account the operational constraints of the battery to preserve its useful life. The first constraint corresponds to its minimum and maximum value of the state of charge ( S O C ), defined by the ratio between the energy stored in the battery and its nominal capacity ( C b a t ). The battery S O C calculation is shown in Eq. (24) and its restriction interval is shown in Eq. (25). (24) S O C ( i ) = ( 1 − σ ) ⋅ S O C ( i − 1 ) + ( 1 − μ ) ⋅ η c h ⋅ P b a t ( i ) ⋅ Δ t − μ ⋅ P b a t ( i ) ⋅ Δ t η r t ⋅ η d i s C b a t (25) S O C m i n ≤ S O C ( i ) ≤ S O C m a x where σ is the battery self-discharge rate (-), Δ t is the simulation time step (0.25 h in this work), P b a t is the battery power ( W ), μ is a binary variable whose value is 1 when P b a t > 0 and 0 when P b a t ≤ 0 (-), η c h is the battery charging efficiency (-) while η r t and η d i s are the round trip and discharge efficiency (-), respectively. The battery also has a restriction related to its maximum charge or discharge power P b a t m a x . In this work, the lithium battery technology was applied whose value of P b a t m a x must be limited to 1/3 of C b a t , as shown in Eq. (26) [33]. Another restriction is related to the maximum charge or discharge power of the battery P b a t m a x , which for the lithium battery, technology used in this work, must be limited to 1/3 of C b a t , according to Eq. (26) [33]. (26) − C b a t 3 ≤ P b a t ( i ) ≤ C b a t 3 Having defined the constraints on battery operation that the HEMS must meet, Fig. 5 shows the Battery Energy Management (BEM) strategy with its 5 modes of operation, which has the following variables that affect its execution of the strategy: S O C , P n e t , P c d , D p e a k and the vector p whose values correspond to each change in energy price during the day and, p = 7, corresponds to the peak period (with highest price). Each battery operating mode has a hierarchy level in the BEM strategy and executes a specific function, but without violating the battery operational constraints (Eqs. (25) and (26)), which are already satisfied in the mathematical formulation that can be seen in detail in [35]. The E x c e s s B a t t e r y C h a r g e mode, positioned as the primary level within the BEM strategy hierarchy, is activated whenever there is an excess of generation ( P n e t < 0 ), aiming to store the maximum surplus of energy. This mode holds particular significance in minimizing the energy subject to feed-in remuneration, which typically incurs lower costs. The stored energy can then be utilized during peak periods (preferably) or for peak shaving, resulting in notable cost savings for the user. In the next hierarchy level is the E x c e s s B a t t e r y C h a r g e mode, which occurs when the SH is consuming energy ( P n e t < 0 ) in the peak period ( p = 7 ), where the battery seeks to supply all the net power demand possible during this period, thus also reducing energy acquisition cost. The P e a k B a t t e r y D i s c h a r g e mode, positioned as the third level, aiming to perform the peak-shaving task when P n e t is higher than the D p e a k , i.e., the battery acts to limit the power consumed from the grid ( P g ) to the value of D p e a k . By the NSGA-3 iteratively adjusting D p e a k based on the feedback from the objective function, this approach is particularly advantageous because it allows for automated fine-tuning, reducing the need for manual intervention and potentially leading to better overall performance. If none of the previously mentioned modes are applicable, the algorithm evaluates P c d ( p ) , which is also determined by the NSGA-3 algorithm. If P c d ( p ) is greater than 0, the D i s c h a r g e B a t t e r y mode is activated. In this mode, the battery discharges at a fixed power equal to P c d ( p ) multiplied by P b a t m a x . Conversely, if P c d ( p ) is less than or equal to 0, the algorithm activates the C h a r g e B a t t e r y mode. Here, the battery is charged at a fixed power equal to P c d ( p ) multiplied by P b a t m a x . This strategy enables the algorithm to dynamically adapt to changing power conditions, ensuring efficient management of the battery capacity based on objective functions”. With the P b a t value defined by the battery energy management strategy, the electrical power demanded by the DNO grid P g r i d is defined by Eq. (27). (27) P g r i d ( i ) = P n e t ( i ) + P b a t ( i ) 2.5 Home energy management system algorithm After presenting and modeling each step of the HEMS in detail, an overview of the developed framework is shown Fig. 6. 3 Mathematical formulation and the proposed optimization algorithm In this section, the mathematical modeling of the objectives functions and the proposed multi-objective optimization algorithm. The thermal resistance method to model the PVT generation is a mathematical formulation with many nonlinear equations, making MILP modeling unfeasible, so this paper apply NSGA-III as a meta-heuristic to deal with the nonlinear model. Thus, NSGA-III will determine the optimal scheduling for the controllable loads and the battery operation parameters ( P c d and D p e a k ), whose purpose is to reach a compromise between energy cost and users’ comfort, forming a Pareto Front containing non-dominated solutions of day-ahead SH operation plans. One of these solutions will be selected by the user to be applied the next day. 3.1 Objective function and restrictions The tariff modality adopted in this paper considers TOU energy price ( C E T O U ) when the SH is consuming energy from the grid ( P g r i d > 0 ), in addition to the feed-in remuneration ( C E f i ) when the SH is injecting energy into the DNO grid ( P g r i d ≤ 0 ). In this way, the energy cost ( C e n e ) in a specific time interval i is defined by Eq. (28). (28) C e n e ( i ) = C E T O U ( i ) ⋅ P g r i d ( i ) ⋅ Δ t if P g r i d ( i ) > 0 C E f i ⋅ P g r i d ( i ) ⋅ Δ t if P g r i d ( i ) ≤ 0 In addition, the tariff scheme adopted in this work also considers a monthly demand cost ( C d e m ), as described in Eq. (29), and the value is divided by 30, which represents the cost in a daily value. Finally, the variation of the energy stored in the battery between the beginning and the end of the day cost ( C e b a t ) as shown in Eq. (30); if this consideration is not taken into account, the optimization algorithm will tend to end the day with the battery completely discharged to reduce the daily energy cost, but the next day the battery will start completely discharged and could significantly affect the system performance. To solve this problem, the cost of this daily variation was inserted into the daily energy cost objective function, meaning that the battery tends to end the day with the same amount of stored energy. A generic description of each chromosome is shown in Table 3. 3.2 Optimization algorithm The multi-objective optimization algorithm used in this work is NSGA-III and, together with the proposed HEMS, should define the optimal day-ahead LS of controllable loads and the battery energy management in order to simultaneously reduce the daily energy costs and maximize the user comfort. Fig. 7 shows the implemented optimization algorithm. 4 Results The methodology proposed in this paper has been implemented in Matlab software and to evaluate its performance, a case study has been carried out using real meteorological data from a meteorological station, a history of consumption of controllable equipment, and the Electrical Appliances Possessions Research for the Residential Sector (PPH Brasil 2019) [40]. 4.1 Day-ahead meteorological data forecast results As detailed in Section 4.1, the historical weather data of a 4-year time horizon has been collected from a meteorological station, with 1-hour of time interval discretization to perform computational experiments with the NARX algorithm. To predict the next full day, each variable is standardized into a vector of 24 elements to represent its daily profile forming an input pattern of 168 attributes (7 input variables) and 1 output variable (target) containing 24 attributes (solar irradiance, air temperature, or wind speed). The data was divided into 3 sets: training (70%), validation (15%), and testing (15%) and the each NARX topology contains 168 inputs, delay of 2 (d = 2), 10 neurons in the hidden layers activated by sigmoid transfer function, 24 outputs activated by linear transfer function and apply Levenberg–Marquardt as optimizer in the training algorithm. The MSE of training, validation, and testing (calculated with normalized variables) of each of the 3 NARX networks to predict the day-ahead irradiance, temperature, and wind speed profile curve are shown in Table 4, being the test set used to measure the quality of the predictions generated by the neural networks using MSE and coefficient of determination ( R 2 ). Observing the MSE values in Table 4, it can be seen that the NARX network obtained the lowest MSE results (0.00458 in the test process) for predicting day-ahead ambient temperature data, i.e., it is easy to have better accuracy in the prediction process for this variable. The irradiance MSE value obtained in the test process was 0.00825, while the wind speed obtained the worst value (testing MSE = 0.0147) because it is the most intermittent of this target and usually is more difficult to predict. The MSE results of the test process for each variable are also compared with a simple algorithm that only replicates the data from the day (t) into day (t+1), being the NARX MSE value obtained in the test procedure is significantly smaller in all cases. Fig. 8, Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 show, respectively, the comparison between the day-ahead real and predicted data for solar irradiance, ambient temperature, and wind speed, obtained from the NARX networks. 4.2 Energy tariff description The tariff scheme adopted in this work is composed of a fixed value of 0.35 BRL 1 1 BRL is the acronym for the currency used in Brazil (Brazilian Real). /kWh for feed-in remuneration and 22.30 BRL/kW for monthly demand cost ( C E d e m ). The TOU tariff adopted has 8 different periods p with the prices varying from between off-peak (the lowest price), shoulder (the intermediate price), and peak (the highest price), whose values per period p are described in Table 5. Finally, the chromosome number or the fixed values of P c d for each period p are also shown in Table 5. 4.3 Battery and PVT module data Battery properties vary according to the type of battery and have improved their performance over time with technological developments. In this work, a lithium-iron-phosphate battery with a nominal capacity of 6 kWh and an initial SOC of 50% has been selected for the case study, and its technical data were obtained from the works of [33,41], as shown in Table 6. Concerning PVT, the system applied in the study case has an installed capacity of 1.82 kWp was selected, consisting of 4 modules ( N m = 4) of 455 Wp and a boiler with a storage capacity of 500 liters ( m b = 500 kg ), whose material specifications are shown in Table 7 and detailed in [14]. 4.4 Occupant behavior results The proposed occupant behavior model described in Section 2 was applied to 10 controllable loads, divided into 8 deferrable (D) and 2 thermal (T) loads. Thus, Table 8 presents the two discrete parameters, turn-on times ( t o ) and duration per cycle ( c d ) of the 10 controllable loads, as well as their nominal active power ( P l ) and priority comfort values ( p r i ). It should be noted that the power of the thermal loads is not fixed and depends on the boiler water temperature ( T b ), as described in Eq. (19) and the daily energy consumed by all controllable loads is 24.69 kWh. The comfort matrix, which is composed of 10 ( N j ) vectors of 96 ( N t ) continuous values, is presented graphically to facilitate data interpretation, as shown in Fig. 11. Analyzing the comfort matrix in Fig. 11, many devices are used very frequently during the 7–10 h period, which is one of the peak periods when energy prices are higher. Therefore, the optimization algorithm must analyze the trade-off between energy cost and user comfort to allocate loads during these periods. However, the inclusion of PVT generation, battery, and boiler provides flexibility, allowing the algorithm to allocate loads during periods of greater comfort with little or no increase in energy cost. 4.5 Consumption profile of the non-controllable loads and the base case The measurements of non-controllable loads are aggregated in a unique meter and their day-ahead load consumption is defined by the average power consumption history of each time interval i has been applied, as shown in Eq. (20). Furthermore, to evaluate the performance of the proposed HEMS model, a base scenario (Base Case) is defined by the average SH consumption history without considering the inclusion of the PVT system and battery in the SH. Thus, Fig. 12 shows the expected daily profile of non-controllable loads consumption and the Base Case scenario. Non-controllable loads are responsible for a consumption of 4.81 kWh per day, which is around 14.21% of the total consumption of SH, and the peak consumption occurs between 18 and 22 h, mainly due to the use of lighting systems. About the Base Case, it has a daily consumption of 33.82 kWh, of which 25.81% (8.76 kWh) occurs during peak hours and the maximum demand is 2.31 kW, making its daily cost ( E c ) BRL 32.73 ( C e n e = BRL 31.01 and C d e m = BRL 1.71). 4.6 Pareto front optimal solutions The meta-heuristic applied in this paper was the NSGA-III. After detailed tests, the algorithm was calibrated with a stopping criterion of 100 iterations, a population of 400 individuals, selection by the roulette wheel, crossover percentage of 50%, and mutation of 50% with a mutation rate of 10%, whose purpose is to find a non-dominated solution set (Pareto Front) considering to minimize the energy cost and maximize the user comfort. The time to perform the simulation was 87 min on a notebook with an AMD Ryzen 7 4800H, 2.90 GHz processor with 8 GB of DDR4 RAM and the Pareto Front obtained is shown in Fig. 13. The Pareto Front shown in Fig. 13 has 53 non-dominated solutions, whose energy cost values vary between BRL 11.10 and BRL 16.17, while the comfort varies between 0.424 and 0.811. To present the results and evaluate the performance of the proposed HEMS, the result of 3 solutions, which are the solution with the highest comfort (called S1 solution), the solution with the lowest cost (S2 solution) and a solution that is at the knee of the curve (S3 solution), which are highlighted in red and their respective chromosome values, energy cost and comfort are shown in Table 9. 4.7 S1 solution results S1 is the solution in which the optimization algorithm allocated the use of the equipment to the times when the user most enjoyed using it, causing the comfort value to reach 0.831, on the other hand, there was a high energy cost in the value of BRL 16.85. Fig. 14 shows the LS for the next day obtained in solution S1. As shown in Fig. 14, the equipment are assigned to turn on during periods of higher comfort, but many of these periods coincide for several loads, increasing the value of the maximum demand by adding the power of the equipment connected at the same time, and also coincide with peak periods. Fig. 15 shows the summed consumption curve of all equipment ( P S H ), the electrical energy generated by the PVT ( P e l ), and the net power in S1 solution ( P n e t ). Consumption profile P S H for S1 solution consumes 28.82 kWh daily, of which 20.05% (5.78 kWh) is consumed during peak periods and the maximum demand was 8.60 kW, giving a high of C e of BRL 29.04 (a reduction of only 14.12% in relation to Base Case). The installation of the PVT system generated enough thermal energy to supply showers, T b > 40 ° C in all day (see Fig. 16), and daily electrical energy of 11.09 kWh, of which 35.35% was consumed locally and 64.66% was fed into the DNO network, which results in a reduction of the maximum demand to 7.62 kW, peak consumption to 4.34 kWh and the value of C e to BRL 21.89. Fig. 16 shows the dynamics of the PVT system throughout the day for S1 solution. Observing Fig. 16, it can be seen that the PVT adds heat ( Q u > 0) to the boiler water between 8:30 and 17:00 h, periods in which it has enough irradiance for the cell temperature ( T c e l l ) to be higher than the T b (the working fluid), while in subsequent periods there is a loss of heat. Another important aspect regarding the thermal dynamics of the PVT is the reduction of T b with the baths, which causes the temperature gradient between the cell and the working fluid to increase, and consequently increases the value of Q u . This shows that the bathing times influence the thermal and electrical efficiency of the PVT, whose daily values were 17.82% and 10.56% respectively, making the overall efficiency of the system 28.38%. Finally, Fig. 17 shows the energy management performed by the battery and P g r i d . By applying the battery energy management strategy, the percentage of energy generated by the PVT exported to the DNO network reduces from 64.66% to 33.68%, the percentage of energy consumed during peak periods reduces from 5.78 kWh to 1.96 kWh and peak demand reduces to 5.62 kW. Thus, after carrying out load shifting and peak shaving, the C e cost reduced to BRL 16.85, showing the effectiveness of the strategy. 4.8 S2 solution results In another hand, the S2 solution is the cheapest non-dominated solution obtained by optimization algorithm, thus, the devices are allocated in suitable times to reduce the energy costs, causing the C e value to reach BRL 11.10 per day, on contrast, there was a low comfort value of 0.424. Fig. 18 shows the LS for the next day obtained in S2 solution. Analyzing Fig. 18, the S2 Solution schedule plan is not feasible, because many devices are allocated to be used at dawn or unfeasible moments in the user’s routine, therefore, we assume that this type of solution should be discarded. To analyze how the system could achieve a cost of only BRL 11.10 per day, Fig. 19 shows the battery power management for S2 solution. Combining the LS, PVT power generation, and battery energy management strategy, the S2 solution only BRL 11.10 per day as it managed to reduce peak demand to 5 kW, in addition to eliminating energy consumption during the peak period and not exporting energy into the DNO network. 4.9 S3 solution results S3 is one of the solutions that is at the knee of the Pareto Front which has the characteristic of having a good compromise between cost and comfort. This solution has a C e value of BRL 11.70 and a comfort value of 0.774, i.e., these are values relatively close to the lowest cost and the greatest comfort. Fig. 20 shows the LS for the next day obtained in S3 solution. As shown in Fig. 20, the devices are scheduled to turn on with high comfort values, similar to the S1 solution, but at a much lower cost for creating the most appropriate LS, as shown in Fig. 21 which shows the electrical power profiles before the battery energy management strategy. The S3 solution consumed about 28.82 kWh of electrical energy, about 17.41% (5.02 kWh) of which occurred during the peak period, and the maximum demand was 5.16 kW, giving a C e value of BRL 24.91 (a reduction 26.34% in relation to Base Case). The electrical power generated by the PVT was 11.12 kWh, almost equal in all Pareto Front solutions because the initial water boiler temperature and the daily time of bath were the same, and around 59.45% of this energy was injected into the DNO grid. So, with this generation, the P n e t power profile for the S3 solution has a peak period consumption of 3.20 kWh and peak power of 3.20 kW, showing that many of the loads were scheduled in the periods of high generation. Finally, Fig. 22 shows the battery energy management and P g r i d . Observing Fig. 22, the battery energy management strategy eliminates the energy consumption during the peak period and the energy exported into the DNO network, in addition to significantly reducing peak demand to 1.99 kW, resulting in a C e cost of BRL 11.70. Therefore, by combining the LS, PVT power generation, and battery energy management strategy, the optimization algorithm can significantly reduce the energy cost maintaining a high level of comfort in this solution. 5 Discussions By presenting the results of 3 non-dominated solutions of the Pareto frontier obtained by NSGA-III, this section aims to carry out a critical analysis of the proposed methodology, showing its advantages and limitations. When analyzing the results of the Pareto frontier solutions, it becomes evident that the solutions (S) with the lowest costs should be avoided (such as the S1 solution and others close to it), since these plans allocate some loads to be used at times that are not feasible for the user to achieve such C e values. Furthermore, with increases of around 1% to 10% in the C e value of the S1 solution, the user has a good option of plans at low costs and with good equipment scheduling times. On the other hand, although S1 solution (and others close to it) allocates equipment at the times most used by the user, its high cost does not make it a good option, since the options at the knee of the curve change the scheduling of equipment very little and reduce costs significantly. However, assigning a maximum cost and minimum comfort constraint of the mathematical modeling in the optimization algorithm will affect the diversity of solutions and, consequently, convergence and its ability to find the optimal (or quasi-optimal) solutions to the problem. One limitation of this approach is that there is no procedure to help users select the most appropriate solution for their context among the non-dominated solutions. One way to mitigate this problem is to discard a percentile of the lowest cost solutions and a percentile of the highest comfort solutions from the Pareto frontier (after the optimization process), but a definitive solution must be investigated in depth. Regarding the performance of the proposed HEMS algorithm when combining the LS, PVT power generation, and battery energy management strategy, some metrics confirm that it has a satisfactory performance, such as reducing the EC by 66.09% when comparing the S3 solution with Base Case, reducing the maximum demand, allocating bathing times so as not to need to heat water with auxiliary resistance (always maintaining T b above 40 ° C ), in addition to eliminating (or almost eliminating) energy injection into the DNO grid and consumption during peak periods (except for some solutions close to S1 solutions). Table 10 summarizes the main results of the 3 Pareto front solutions presented. The PVT system can provide all (or almost all) of the thermal energy needed to keep the water in the baths at 40 °C, eliminating the cost of electricity to do so. For the Pareto Front solutions, the daily thermal, electrical, and overall system efficiencies were approximately 11.25%, 17.85%, and 29.10%, respectively, with the overall efficiency reaching a maximum variation of 2.18% between the solutions. If most of the baths take place in the morning, the boiler water temperature will decrease, reducing the cell temperature and increasing the electrical and thermal efficiencies. However, the boiler water temperature may drop below 40 °C and require the use of auxiliary resistance heating, demonstrating the difficulty of managing the thermal dynamics of the system and the benefit of scheduling baths appropriately. Finally, it should be noted that if the initial boiler water temperature were much lower (e.g., 25 °C), the thermal efficiency of the system would increase significantly and bath scheduling could provide much greater savings. The proposed methodology presented a satisfactory performance based on the metrics presented in Table 10, especially for solutions close to the knee of the curve, presenting consumption plans with high energy cost savings, trying to have as little impact as possible on the user’s routines. The proposed approach has the limitation of not considering the battery degradation’s cost, which could be incorporated into the objective function E c to ponder its impact. As the decarbonization of the energy sector plays a central role in mitigating the problems caused by climate change, including the amount of equivalent CO 2 emissions as a new objective function must be evaluated. Finally, evaluating how the errors in the generation and consumption forecasts impact the performance of the proposed methodology must be deeply evaluated. 6 Conclusions The optimal system solutions considering the combination of LS, PVT power generation, and battery energy management strategy were obtained in this paper through a newly proposed methodology using NSGA-III as optimization algorithms. The case study conducted showed a significant cost reduction of 66.09% in the S3 solution, which makes the economic viability of HEMS implementation in real applications promising. This result was achieved by allocating loads to periods of surplus generation and periods of lower cost, combined with efficient load shifting and peak shaving performed by the battery energy management system, whose performance is also proven by the elimination of energy exported to the DNO grid, reducing the maximum demand by 68.46% and almost eliminating consumption in the peak period. An important advantage of the proposed method is its universality, it can be applied in any house and any place, as long as it has a monitoring and automation system that contains the historical consumption data of each controllable load, the total consumption of the uncontrollable load and the meteorological variables. For future works, the research group seeks to evaluate how the errors in the generation and consumption forecasts affect the methodology performance. The main computational effort of the algorithm is related to solving the resistance method to calculate the PVT power generation, so applying a simpler method to calculate this generation is a priority to make the processing architecture of the algorithm more compact and cheaper. As the Pareto frontier offers multiple solutions, another future work is to develop a procedure that facilitates users in selecting the most suitable solution for their context. Finally, the energy dynamic and occupant behavior of using electric cars, the consideration of emissions as an objective function and the aggregation of several SHs to form a virtual power plant are also being investigated. coredata.dc:description: The environmental impact on the energy sector has become a significant concern, necessitating the implementation of Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS) to enhance the energy efficiency of buildings, reduce costs and greenhouse gas emissions, and ensure user comfort. This paper presents a novel approach to provide optimal day-ahead energy management plans in smart homes with Photovoltaic/Thermal (PVT) systems, aiming to achieve a balance between energy cost and user comfort. This multi-objective problem employs the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III as the optimization algorithm and the Nonlinear Auto-regressive with External Input to forecast the day-ahead meteorological variables, which serve as inputs to predict the PVT electrical and heat production in the thermal resistance model. The HEMS benefits from the time-of-use tariff due to the flexibility provided by the energy storage from a battery bank and a boiler. Furthermore, it performs a load scheduling for 10 controllable loads based on three feature parameters to characterize occupant behavior. A study case analysis revealed a cost reduction of approximately 66% in the solution close to the knee of the Pareto curve (S3 solution). The environmental impact on the energy sector has become a The PVT heat production was sufficient to meet the thermal demand of the showers. The proposed hybrid battery management model effectively eliminated the export of electricity to the grid, reducing consumption during peak periods and the maximum peak demand.
